title: 113_hr5703
content: The "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property and specifies the appropriate congressional committees. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for US cultural diplomacy, as it reflects respect for other cultures and the shared heritage of humanity. Instances of loss, damage, and destruction of cultural property have occurred due to various threats like political instability, armed conflict, and natural disasters. For example, in Egypt, political unrest led to the ransacking of museums, resulting in the destruction of ancient artifacts. Similarly, in Iraq, the looting of the Iraq Museum after Saddam Hussein's fall resulted in the loss of around 15,000 items, including valuable ancient amulets. In Iraq and Syria, cultural heritage sites have been devastated by looting, shelling, and destruction by groups like ISIS/ISIL, resulting in irreparable loss of ancient artifacts and historical treasures. In Syria and Iraq, ISIS/ISIL has destroyed cultural sites and artifacts, including the Tomb of Jonah, to eradicate minorities. In Mali, Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in Timbuktu, threatening ancient manuscripts. In Afghanistan, the Taliban decreed the destruction of the Bamiyan Buddhas, ancient statues in central Afghanistan, leading to worldwide condemnation. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed Buddhist temples, statues, and literature after seizing power in 1975. They also targeted mosques for destruction. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge destroyed Buddhist temples, statues, and literature after seizing power in 1975, as well as mosques and Catholic churches. In China, the Cultural Revolution led to the destruction of antiques and old Beijing, with efforts now to rebuild lost architectural heritage. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art, artifacts, and archives, partially damaging the 17th century city of Jacmel. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damaged cultural sites like Mahabalipuram in India, Sun Temple of Koranak, and Old Town of Galle in Sri Lanka. This destruction represents an irreparable loss of humanity's cultural heritage. The destruction of cultural properties like the Temple of Koranak and the Old Town of Galle in Sri Lanka is a loss for all. The US Armed Forces have played a crucial role in preserving cultural property since President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas in 1943. The Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams, known as the "Monuments Men," were formed during World War II to protect cultural property. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield was established in 2006 to support the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in Armed Conflict. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield, founded in 2006, aims to protect international cultural property at risk of destruction due to various threats like political instability, armed conflict, and natural disasters, in line with the 1954 Hague Convention. The U.S. aims to protect international cultural property at risk of destruction due to political instability, armed conflict, or disasters, in accordance with the 1954 Hague Convention and international law. This includes preventing the importation of pillaged cultural property and ensuring compliance with existing laws and regulations. The U.S. aims to protect cultural property at risk of destruction during political instability, armed conflict, or disasters. Measures include preventing trafficking in stolen cultural property through existing laws and regulations. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection is established under Section 4. The President appoints a White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection to coordinate and promote efforts involving multiple Federal agencies, submit annual reports to congressional committees, provide policy recommendations, and resolve interagency differences efficiently. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection is responsible for submitting annual reports on interagency efforts to protect international cultural property, providing policy recommendations, resolving interagency differences, and collaborating with various domestic and international actors. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities related to the Hague Convention during armed conflicts. This includes procedures to safeguard cultural property at risk and actions taken in conflicts involving the United States. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including actions taken in conflicts involving the United States. The Administrator of USAID is also required to submit information on efforts to protect international cultural property. The Administrator of USAID and the Secretary of Defense must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities, coordination with other agencies, and development programs. The Secretary of Defense must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities under the Hague Convention and other agreements, to the White House Coordinator. This includes directives, policies, and actions taken to safeguard cultural property at risk of destruction from various causes. The Department of Justice, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including actions taken to avoid damage through construction activities abroad. This includes directives, policies, and regulations instituted to safeguard cultural property at risk of destruction from political instability, armed conflict, or natural disasters. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must report to the White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection on Department of Justice efforts to protect international cultural property, including statutes and regulations used in criminal actions to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property. The Department of Justice conducts criminal and civil actions to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property, including investigations into organized crime. They also ensure consistent application of laws for international cultural property, whether located abroad or attempted to be imported into the United States. Authorization for federal agencies to engage in international cultural property protection activities with the Smithsonian Institution is granted under Section 6 of the Act. The Department of State, Defense, USAID, Homeland Security, Justice, Interior, National Archives, National Science Foundation, and other agencies can partner with the Smithsonian Institution to temporarily use their personnel for international cultural property protection activities. Federal agencies can cover the salaries and expenses of Smithsonian personnel assisting in these activities. Federal agencies can pay for salaries and expenses of Smithsonian personnel to assist in international cultural property protection activities, including support for military, diplomatic, and law enforcement efforts. The Secretary of State is authorized to make grants for international cultural property protection activities in areas at risk of destruction. Additionally, emergency protection for Syrian cultural property is provided for. The President will apply import restrictions to archaeological or ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. These restrictions will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The Act mandates import restrictions on archaeological or ethnological material of Syria within 60 days of enactment. Definitions include cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria since August 18, 2011, and the term "State Party" refers to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act.
